recipe.name: Shrimp / Prawn Pad Thai (Spice I Am Restaurant Recipe)
recipe.description: This is an authentic recipe for Pad Thai from the Spice I Am cookbook, one of the most critically acclaimed Thai restaurants in Sydney. This is a very traditional recipe for those who like truly authentic Thai street food as the dried shrimp flavour is stronger than what you get in westernised Pad Thai recipes. For something more like what you get at mainstream Thai restaurants, use this Everyday Pad Thai recipe.
recipeIngredient: 5 oz / 150 g   dried Pad Thai rice noodles ((Note 1))
3 oz / 80 g   firm tofu (, cut into small matchsticks)
1.5 oz / 45 g   roasted unsalted peanuts (, finely ground)
2 tbsp garlic chives (, cut into 3/4" / 2cm lengths)

recipeInstructions.text: Place the rice noodles in a bowl and cover with lukewarm water and set aside for 1 hour. (Note 7) Drain then set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Place the rice noodles in a bowl and cover with lukewarm water and set aside for 1 hour. (Note 7) Drain then set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 2 tbsp of the oil in a wok or large heavy based fry pan over medium heat. Add the prawns and cook until they just change colour. (Note 8) Remove from the wok and set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Heat 2 tbsp of the oil in a wok or large heavy based fry pan over medium heat. Add the prawns and cook until they just change colour. (Note 8) Remove from the wok and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the shallot and stir fry for 2 minutes. Then add the tofu, dried shrimp, fish sauce, palm sugar and tamarind puree and cook for 1 minute until the sugar has dissolved.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the rice noodles, vinegar and 2 tsp chili powder and stir fry for 2 minutes.

recipeInstructions.text: Turn the heat down to low and push the noodles to one side. Add the remaining 2 tbsp of oil into the wok then the egg.

recipeInstructions.text: Push the noodles over the egg and stir, scraping the base of the wok so the egg scrambles and mixes in with the noodles.

recipeInstructions.text: Remove from heat. Add half the peanuts, most of the bean sprouts, garlic chives, prawns and toss gently.

recipeInstructions.text: Transfer to serving platter. Sprinkle with white sugar and remaining peanuts. Serve immediately with lime wedges on the side and sprinkled with extra chili powder, if desired.

review.reviewBody: Cooked this last night along with your Thai Basil Chicken for my wedding anniversary.  Incredible. Hubby doesn’t like westernised Thai food and he mostly avoids Thai food here which he actually really likes in Thailand! Well he loved it! Thankfully now I have something to do with my enormous pot of Thai Basil. Pad Thai is my fav and this was so good.
I doubled the recipe following the instructions for 6 persons. The taste was too salty (dried shrimps combined with the fish sauce). Not sure I will follow this recipe again.

Tasty and quick, just as described. I will try your other Pad Thai recipe tho as there is just something that I'm searching for to match my favourite Pad Thai memory, maybe the dried shrimp in that recipe will do the trick. Fingers crossed.

Coming back to this one to say I think I've found a workaround for when dried shrimp (which I agree are 100% essential) are out of stock or otherwise hard to source. If you buy whole raw prawns and de-shell them yourself, you can bake the heads and shells (I blast at 220 for 15 minutes then 135 for an hour) to cook and completely dry them out, then blend into a fine powder which can be used either as instructed, or to sprinkle over in the end as a condiment. The best part is that the amount of prawn shells/heads you need to make 50g of dried powder is almost the exact amount you'll end up with after processing the raw prawns required for the rest of the recipe. It's a little extra legwork and it may not be quite as potent as the factory produced stuff, but it's neat to be able to use up the parts of the prawn that might otherwise get chucked away.

Hi Nagi, just cooked this tonight x flavours were great x authentic, except i think i used the wrong dried shrimp. they were not tiny, maybe 3cm long. i did chop them up as small as i could but the larger pieces made my pad thai have chewy bits. should i have bought different dried shrimp?

I just made this. EASILY better than any takeout I’ve ever tried. And finally I know what’s in my food and how many calories I’m eating. This is a win-win for sure. Next I will try your chicken Pad Thai, I was just feeling adventurous tonight and I have no regrets.

Never found a better Pad Thai recipe than this, and the tips you include are incredibly helpful! If dried shrimp were a little easier to get hold of here in Scotland then I'd make it every week. Kicking myself for not buying Sujet's book while it was still in print here though
